_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Purpose: Pursuant to 40 CFR Part 68, executive summary for the Risk Management Plan pertaining to High Purity Products stationary source at 14546 N Lombard St, Portland, OR 97203.

1.0	The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at High Purity Products (HPP) at 14546 N Lombard Street, Portland, OR 97203:

1.1	Accidental Release Prevention. 
1.1.1	Receiving, Shipping and Warehousing procedures outlining proper and safe work practices to ensure safe and compliant execution of the process.
1.1.1.1	New chemical approval procedure.
1.1.1.2	Container inspection, upon arrival, to ensure integrity.
1.1.1.3	On Hold and lockout/tag out procedures.
1.1.1.4	Personal protective equipment plan.

2.0	HPP's facility and the regulated substances covered by 40 CFR Part 68. 

2.1	HPP's Lombard facility, storage facility where we store and ship Hydrochloric Acid in sealed containers, in quantities exceeding the threshold, per 40 CFR Part 68.
2.2	HPP's Lombard facility.
2.2.1	HPP has a generator to ensure life safety equipment is operational in the event of a power outage.
2.2.2	The storage area is surrounded by containment curbing to prevent a release to the environment and mitigate the spread of the spill through the building. 
2.2.3	The storage area is rated as an H-4 storage area per the International Building Code (IBC). 

3.0	HPP's accidental release prevention program. 

3.1	Process Safety Management Plan
3.1.1	Employees are put through an extensive series of trainings and test to ensure competency before they can work around a covered process. 
3.1.2	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is performed before the implementation of a new process. 
3.1.3	Pre-start up safety review is completed after the PHA. 
3.1.4	An extensive list of operating procedures to ensure the safest practices while working. 
3.1.5	Contractor safety procedures to ensure optimum safety. 
3.1.6	Preventative maintenance program. 
3.1.7	Procedures for management of cha

nge. 
3.1.8	Incident documentation and investigation to determine root cause of the incident and make preventative improvements. 
3.1.9	Compliance audits to ensure continued compliance and safety.

4.0	Five-year accident history. 

4.1	HPP has not had an accidental release of Hydrochloric Acid in the last five years at any HPP location, including HPP's Lombard location. 

5.0	Emergency response.

5.1	HPP's emergency response plan is pending inclusion to the community emergency response plan, per the Multnomah County LEPC Chairman, Jim Dunlap. 
5.2	HPP has a policy to ensure a certain number of HAZWOPPER trained personnel onsite while the facility is open for operation.
5.3	Overview of regulations pertaining to accidental release reporting and other safe practices to ensure the safety of the employees, the surrounding civilians and environment. 
5.4	Predetermined incident command structure. 
5.4.1	On-Site Incident commander is ultimately responsible for the coordination of the emergency plan and assumes leadership duties. 
5.4.2	Evacuation coordinator reports to On-Site Incident Commander and ensures facility is evacuated, determines primary assembly point, etc.
5.4.3	Safety Officer is responsible for the overall safety of the emergency response operation. Ultimately, these duties can be assumed by the On-Site Incident Commander. 
5.5	HPP Also has recently integrated an Emergency Response Exercise Program into its emergency response plans, per 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart E. 

6.0	Planned and recent changes to improve safety. 

6.1	The implementation of randomized safety and compliance inspections. 
6.2.1	More inclusive onsite trainings. 
6.3	A Compliance Director position was recently integrated into HPP's management structure to ensure and improve the overall safety and compliance of HPP. 

7.0	HPP is committed to ensuring the safest practices are consistently executed to ensure the safety of its employees, the surrounding community, and the env
